The reason we have two nostrils is because we evolved from earlier mammals/tetrapods who already had 2 nostrils, who in turn evolved from fish which had two nares. I imagine having "stereo" smelling/chemical detection would be more beneficial in water. Then again, the first fish were also very small, so maybe it wasn't that important. Vertebrate bodies to favor symmetry though, so maybe its just an "lucky accident."
Now that I think about it, I actually don't know how far back the sense of smell/chemical detection goes in our evolutionary history, or what the first of our ancestors to have two nostrils/nares/openings would have been. I kinda feel like it would be predate even the first chordate, as other animals(such as flat worms and even arthropods) have two "nostrils", though I actually don't know if they're homologous(though if they homologous, I suppose that would be good evidence that having two is significantly better than having just one.)

10 Answers

￼

Braxton Boren, Assistant Professor, Audio Technology at American University (2017-present)

Answered September 14, 2017

Originally Answered: How is it that we're able to distinguish a sound in front of us from one behind?

The Head-Related Transfer Function (HRTF) is the set of cues that lets you localize where a sound is coming from. This includes differences in arrival time and loudness at your ears, as well as frequency-dependent filtering from your outer ears (pinnae) and head/torso which are slightly different from the front and back. If you listen to binaural content using someone else’s HRTF, you would not be as good at telling front sources from back sources.

Head movements help differentiate between front and back sources. If a source is at 45 degrees to your front-right or 45 degrees to your rear-right, it will generate roughly the same time and loudness differences at both ears, so it’s hard to tell the difference based on these cues. But if you move your head 5 degrees to the left, your right ear gets closer to a front source but farther from a rear source. Your auditory system can parse this difference, and in fact if your head is not allowed to move, you will be much worse at telling front from back sources.

The visual system trains the auditory system, so if you see the source you are much more likely to think it’s coming from in front of you, even if it’s actually behind you. If we play a recording of a bird behind you and you see a bird in front of you, you’ll likely have a front-back reversal. For this reason it’s more common to mis-localize frontal sources in the rear (because anything you can’t see is assumed to be behind you) rather than the converse.

We’re not perfect at front-back discrimination, even using all these cues. People have reversals all the time even under ideal acoustic conditions.

Does this mean there is really no empirical perspective of anything? What we see is a reaction of the light and our eyes...taste is the reaction of our tongues to the matter...and hearing, smelling, same thing. Interesting. I do remember a video where you asked about whether red looks like the same red to someone else...and this is something I thought of when I was about 10 years old. I wondered if what I was seeing was what others were seeing...like, does it look the same, and if not, how would we know, since we are both adapted to describing things using the same words? Your green might be called red and my red called green...we would never know that the colors were actually different. And the sounds we hear...they are filtered by our ears...so what do they actually sound like....with no filtering? Just the raw sound independent of a filter? Well...wouldn’t that be no sound at all? So...maybe sound only exists, because it’s our body’s reaction to the vibrations emitted by vibrating things. Maybe there’s another form of life that detects music some other way. this stuff always makes me wonder whether every measurement we take is essentially, based on how something interacts with our various human observational mechanisms. so, no humans, no reality as we know it. get where i'm going? reality may have this agreed upon objective data set. but this is really just measurement we all have compared to measure based on our own perspective. all of it is still interpreted via our own observational mechanism; even if it's just our brain.
edit: then you have people out there saying that subjective data doesn't mean much, while objective data means everything... so all they're basically saying is unless we can all agree on a perspective, it's invalid? what it something has unidentified dependencies; say, faith... i guess, in this case, noone is definitely right or wrong for absolute certainty. i can almost bhear the idot responmse to this right now: "well it's about evidence!" uh huh... and what evidence exactly would something with unidentifiable traits and unknowable prerogatives leave, precisely? how would we, then, compare and contrast this with a control system absent of such an influence to gain proper perspective?

So then are scented cleaners (Pine tree freshness) more effective or less effective than unscented ones, because there’s something added? Or is it maybe “unscented” molecules are added to displace, or “mask” the scented molecules (whether pleasant or not) that are a chemical byproduct.

This is why I love Vsause. The questions you want answers to are explained, but only seem to raise more questions. Such as...

Why is something considered odourless? Do our membranes not react to certain molecules, or is it that our brains can’t effectively translate the information? Maybe “No-Smell” molecules such as Natural Gas are simply so relatively close to the odour produced by the human body that we can’t distinguish between the two.

Experiment: Don’t shower for a week, and then take a waft of Natural Gas before the “Sulfur smelling” additives are well... added. See if there’s a noticeable smell. If you still can’t smell anything noticeable, perhaps the NG is being overpowered by local sources. Hint: take a shower. Regardless.

The smell/memory thing is for real. I went through an earthquake as a kid. We lived up in the mountains, in a box canyon. After the quake, a massive dust cloud settled over our home. The smell of the dust was heavy with the scent of cedar trees. It was terrifing. My parents were running around shutting windows, worried that we would suffocate. One day, 3 or 4 years later, I came home from school. Unbeknownst to me, a cedar tree in our yard was being chopped down in segments. We had about 30 stairs from the driveway to our front door. About 2/3 of the way up, I panicked and crouched down in absolute terror for no discernable reason. My sister saw me and helped me into the house. It took me a bit to connect the dots, but I eventually realized that the smell of the cedar dust had triggered a panic attack, due to my memory of the earthquake. It was at that point that I realized just how innately and intensely smell is tied to memory.

think how odd one nostril would look. Well it would look odd to us know, seeing as nearly everybody on the planet has 2. But if we, as humankind, always had one, and animals that have nostrils would have one as well. Then no one would every know. It would look normal. I wonder if it would be one small one in the middle or a big one. Also, I feel like having that second nostril that doesn't breathe as well traps the smell in so we can tell good or bad or smell better. I mean after all, when we smell smoke and we can't see the fire or we don't know where it comes from, or human instincts cause a fear instinct. Or when we smell something bad we want to get away from, not just because it smells bad, but our brain knows that bad smells often mean bad things for the human body. We hold our breath. If we only had one nostril then if we smelled something bad, we would not breathe through our nose. We would breathe through our mouth. Imagine if we didn't have a mouth and only had one nostril. We would hold our breath with a bad smell and now we can't breathe. The advantage of having a mouth and a nose is very very very useful, we just don't think about it or have situations where we thank the use of both in our first world societies

Amazing videos and very educational. Being Greek, I could instantly understand the root of the term Anosmia and anosmic. Οσμή (osmi) = odor,  so an-osmic its a term really used in Greek to describe someone who lacks the sense of smell. In parallel, ageusic, is the one who lacks the sense of taste, since, γεύσις (geusis) means taste, so a-geusia. Just a small...etymological note on yr really interesting clip.

That thing about smell an memory is interesting. I think I experienced this recently. There was a power outage at a building I work at. I went outside near the generator that had automatically kicked on. It happened to be a diesel generator and gave off a very familiar smell. I was instantly and strongly reminded of my experience in the military, working in the motor pool at a base in Korea. I had gone past this generator before when it was running, as they test it weekly. But this day was particularly cold and someone nearby was also smoking a cigarette.

Those combinations tripped that memory and made me feel immediately nostalgic and even had me visualizing the motor pool momentarily, things that never happened on previous experiences with that generator. All the conditions had to be just right, with the correct proportions of odors.

Of course, the smell of diesel exhaust (especially particularly dirty exhaust) is not that common in my every day life now. Most vehicles are not diesels or at least burn diesel a LOT more cleanly than back in the late nineties. But the old Hummers that we drove were always in mediocre condition (at best) and as such burned a bit dirty, and thus had that specific smell consistent with the generator (which spends most of its time off and thus burns a bit dirty when it initially turns on).

We have two nostrils because of symmetry. Generally speaking, any characteristic or organ on the centre line, we have one of, e.g. heart, nose, mouth, spine, head, stomach, arse, willy etc. Anything either side of the centre line, we have two of, e.g. lungs, arms, testicles, ovaries, kidneys, nostrils, ears, nipples etc. Basically, we would probably have two nostrils whether there was a benefit or not.

having ONLY 2 ears also makes no sense. unlike eyes which measure the angle, ears do only measure the existence of something. 2 ears can measure a difference in the time a sound traveled. In 2d space this leaves you with a hyperbole. (aka you can't even tell if it was behind or in front leave alone the distance). In 3d space this resolves in a rotational hyperbole. YES one ear is a bit higher than the other. BUT that only shifts the axis over. Theoretically we need 4 ears. No 3 in a line, no 4 in a plane.

I am anosmic, meaning that I was born without a sense of smell.  My brain is oversize for my head, so the brain casing filled up where the upper chamber of the sinus cavity should be, so the olfactory nerve sensors never formed.  Smells and spatial information are stored in the same place in the brain (I forget the name).  Since I never recorded smells in that region of the brain, there was more room to store spatial information.  As a result, I was a whiz at geometry.  It was really weird.  As soon as I saw a picture or understood the problem to be solved, I instantly new the answer without trying.   But from what people have told me, I'd give it up just so I could smell a woman's perfume

My hypothesis on why smell is so closely tied to our limbic system is that it's a evolutionary remnant relationship. Even significantly less evolved organisms (e.g. the Platyhelminthes) present a rudimentary sense of smell called chemotaxis, more specifically they have receptors that bind to certain molecules that will make them move towards that stimulus or away from it. They are also some of the first few organisms to have some sort of nervous system so basing sensation of of them we could understand how the most important sensation is tied closer with survival than the rest, and that's what the limbic system boils down to in the end, fight or flight instinct.

So good! Just wanted to point out that "olfactory" probably doesn't have that much to do with the word "factory". From latin "olfactus", past participle of "olfacere", that is made out of the words "olere" (to smell) and "facere" (produce, make). I think "olfactory" directly comes from latin "olfactus" rather than being a composite word made in english language (ol+factory), even though the word "factory actually comes from latin "facere" as well.

Some traits aren't selected for specifically, instead they can simply just not be selected against. Take male nipples for example. All my life I  have not had a sense of smell. To this day My family and I are still unsure if the reason behind this is a birth defect or a side effect of chicken pox. As I was growing up, No one (including my family, friends etc) Belived that I  did not have a sense of smell, They thought I was making it up. It wasn't until one day me and my dad set a trap to catch a  raccoon did they finnaly believe me. To my fortune, We had accidently caught a skunk. My dad had wanted to KILL the skunk with a 22. riflle, But  me being against killing for no reason Begged him not too. So, he allowed me to keep thte skunk alive and release him from this trap if I were to put a tarp over him, and release the mechanism to let him out. I agreed, And took  the tarp over to the cage to let him out. As I was spreading out the tarp to let him out, He sprayed my arm with skunk juice (which was light green/yellowish) And my dad gagged up his lungs practicly. And this conclusively proves I am right!!!!


When tracking down the tantalizing smell of prey, a shark relies more on which nostril first detects the scent than the strength of the odor, a new study has found.
The report, published online Thursday in the journal Current Biology, provides a better sense of how these streamlined predators are able to pinpoint distant prey.
Scientists had long thought that the concentration of the smell determined how a shark would react to it, said lead study author Jayne Gardiner, a marine biologist at the University of South Florida in Tampa.
Gardiner and co-workers showed that, instead, sharks take note of which nostril smells the odor first. The scientists showed this by harnessing sharks in a tank and fitting tubes to the animals' nostrils. Then they puffed a burst of squid-scented seawater into one nostril — followed by a puff of squid scent into the other just a fraction of a second later.
When the right nostril received the scent first, the shark would turn to the right. When the left nostril got it first, the animal would turn to the left, no matter the scent's concentration level.

This really does not make much sense, I think it is to detect the direction of a smell.
He says our sense of smell if not good enough to localize one nostril over the other but I would disagree. Like the ears they send signals to the brain and if was can detect direction from sound signals it see sensible to assume we can do the same with smell signals.
Indeed sounds move much faster than smells 340.29 m / s a 20mpm wind (fairly fast) is 8 m/s so 340/8= a ratio of about 45 so it would seems the nose does not even need to be as sensitive to smell as sound, which mean they can afford to be closer together and indeed they are!!

And of course his 'explanation' does not really explain why we have two nostrils, whilst it might be a interesting fact I don't think it explain why we have two nostrils particularly, indeed we could have one with each side having different sensitivity.
Or we could have 3 or 4 or 10 or why not 1,000,0000?

So don't qualify as an explanation in my book, far from it.

Further more the fact dogs can follow scents seems to suggest they can detect direction.

So his video sounds like rubbish to me. A lot of these scientists are not as smart as they make out they are. I thnk we know form experience we can usually tell where a smell comes from,


And the ability to detect the direction of a smell would be useful evolutionary trait so it kind of seems likely we have developed that ability..

In short I say this video is bollocks!

The word 'olfactory' has its origin in Latin. It was taken from the word 'olfactorius'. Olfactorius means 'used to sniff at'. It was derived from 'olfactus' which is a past participle of 'olfacere'. 'Olfacere' means to smell. Olfacere is made up of two parts: Olere and facere. Olere means to smell and 'facere' is to do. Anything that relates to or contributes to the sense of smell is referred to as 'olfactory'.

There's a scientific reason why some people might hate/love broccoli. There's a chemical in some vegetables called PTC. Not everyone can taste it. The ones who can say it tastes extremely bitter; they're called Supertasters. The people that can kind of taste it say it tastes bad, but bearable; they're medium tasters. People who can't taste it, don't taste anything. That could be the reason why some people don't like broccoli. It could be because they are supertasters and find broccoli bitter.

They don't. They just release gases, and we call it smelling (or stinking, depending on how sweaty your feet are). This is the fascinating thing, our noses MAKE the smell. I love science.

Exactly. In order to survive, our brains are hard-wired for change which might be a danger (i.e. with sight, a lion leaping, or with smell, acrid smoke) and are therefore less sensitive to background things, because, if they have been there for a long time already, they are unlikely to be a threat. This happens with every sense. As well as sight and smell, you appreciate a new food most at the first bite, you don't notice traffic-noise if you live in the city, etc.

However, if there was gravity, it would pull the air towards it's source, into clumps and collections (like stars). If there was enough air, it's own gravity would make these clumps, holding it together in a big cloud.
It is helpful to imagine gases in space as clouds of dust - just smaller. Throw up some dust, even on Earth (to a lesser extent), it expands out among the air, striving for equilibrium. Shine light through dust air and it is more or less evenly spaced.

We actually have four nostrils; two you can see; two you can't. This discovery came from observing how fish breath. Fish get their oxygen from the water. Most of them then have 2 pairs of nostrils, a forward-facing set for letting water in and a pair of ' exhaust pipes' for letting them out. The question is, if humans evolved from fish, where did the other 2 nostrils go? The answer is that they migrated backward inside the head to become internal nostrils called choanne - Greek for funnels.

Actually, they can. Sort of like lungs and kidneys, only one testicle is truly necessary. It depends on the person, of course, but for the most part, men with one testicle can have a perfectly normal sex life. Plus, even if it were true that one testicle would prevent an adequate amount of sperm being produced, it would not explain why mammals developed two small testicles, rather than one big one that produces twice as much sperm.

Its easier for them to get damaged, but since mammals usually run such high internal body temperature, sperm wouldn't be able to be produced at the high temperatures inside the body. Testicles are a full 3 degrees cooler than internal organs, and that's so sperm can survive longer. There are also some theories that have to do with external testicles allowing females to make sure a male is fertile and healthy before mating.

Basically taste is a derivation of both stimuli from your tongues' taste buds , and the nerves in your nose. Molecules of food or anything you eat/smell interact with those nerves in your mouth and nose, and these signals are then combined on the way to your brain, arriving as a sweet, bitter, sour or salty taste. Your brain cannot determine what you are eating if it s not receiving information from both your mouth and nose nerves.

YES. By why jump to animals? What about different people? Different people have different noses too. Do different people interpret the smell of a substance differently? Yes. Same goes for all of our senses.

Think about this: what you and I perceive as "red" may actually appear very different. But we can not know because what we have come to know as "red" will always be the same to us. My red may look like your blue, but we both call it red.

(still not an expert) Further, if you are wondering about why stars are covered in "flames" it is because they fuse hydrogen atoms to produce new, larger atoms, releasing large quantities of energy in the form of heat and light (and other stuff). This is not combustion. Stars DO produce oxygen which can be used to fuel more reactions, but these are still fusion reactions, not combustion reactions.

(not an expert) They don't. At least not how I think you mean. 

If you see a flame in space it is because there is oxygen there. Earth is in space and it has oxygen in its atmosphere. Also, just because something emits light does not mean it is on fire. Photons (light particles) are released when electrons drop to lower energy levels.

But an explosion is just the rapid release of energy. This could happen in space without oxygen and combustion would not occur (no flame).

Ok, time for a lesson in rudimentary logic. There's this thing called burden of proof and is a cornerstone of linear logic.

It states:
1. He who makes a claim must supply evidence to support that claim. If you claim there's a god YOU must supply evidence to back it up.
2. It's impossible to disprove a negative. For example it is impossible to disprove the existance on unicorns. It's not my job to prove the non existance of god.

Imagine putting your hand under really hot water, and your other hand under really cold water. Without knowing which is which, initially it can be quite difficult to distinguish the really hot water from the really cold.

When you eat something cold, like icecream, the roof of your mouth gets cold (as you generally squeeze it between the roof of your mouth and your tongue). The roof of your mouth is a sensory 'gray area', and your body interprets it as your frontal brain being cold,  i.e. it's a bit inaccurate in locating where the 'cold' it. Your body begins to direct heat towards the front of your brain, leading to brain freeze (so it's actually brain heat - heat and cold are actually very similar sensations).

I think you've misunderstood the meaning of 'theory.' It means a valid explanation of a certain aspect, based on a body of facts that have been repeatedly, empirically confirmed through observation and experiment.
Gravity, bacteria and plate tectonics are all just theories. Sure, some theories are more speculative such as M-theory, but evolution is not one of them. Understanding the workings of Genetics and natural selection lets you understand that evolution seems as logically certain as 1+1=2.

and your brain uses its experience to request foods that contain it. This is why one day you will really enjoy e.g. bread because you were extra low on the carbohydrates it contains. It's also why almost everything with lots of fat tastes fantastic because when we were evolving we needed to stockpile fat to avoid starving when we didn't know where the next meal was coming from. It's also why pregnant women crave so many weird foods - they need a big range of nutrients to put a baby together! :)

My best answer: like smell, taste is the body's function to sample something before you ingest it to make sure it's not bad for you and will contain things you need to keep alive and well. What your body feels it needs is based on its "nature" (your personal genetic makeup) and also its "nurture" (what you have taught it to enjoy during your lifetime), adjusted by what you have not eaten enough of recently. When you crave something, it's because your body knows that it requires certain nutrients

Sharks also use a wide variety of other organs to locate prey; sharks have excellent vision and hearing, they use an organ called a lateral line to detect motion in the water, and another organ called the apullae of Lorenzini, which can detect the faint electromagnetic fields given off by all living creatures. By combining all of these senses, sharks can track down prey in the vast open ocean.

Technically speaking, nothing can smell anything from miles away. A shark has a very powerful olfactory system, which can detect blood in seawater at a ratio of one part per million. It can then determine the direction the blood is coming from by using its widely placed nostrils, similar to the way we use our ears to determine the direction a sound came from.

No, the lion wouldn't be able to smell it instantly. Rather, the prey is constantly shedding skin and hair, which gets caught up in the wind and blown across the savannah. Many predators have much more sensitive olfactory receptors in their nose, so they can detect a smaller number of certain particles than humans can. The lion can then home in on the scent until they find their prey. The lion, however, cannot smell something downwind of itself because the wind is blowing the scent away.

Not true, entirely. If nothing ever evolved with organs capable of interpreting different wavelengths as a sound... Then the whole world would be void of sound regardless of the source. Sound is caused by our brains, when i snap my fingers "sound" isn't emitted from them, the waves of energy are carried through the air, through the middle ear bones, eventually converted into neuronal signals to my brain to be interpreted as sound. If any part of that chain is broken, there is NO sound.

Sorry, limited # of characters. "S-R" = Stimulus-Response. State system ~ all senses. Habituation eg: a clock makes a tick tock sound - if you are in the room with it for a long time, you stop noticing it (useless, repeated stimulus). Sensitization eg: watching a scary movie, you get a tense, on-edge feeling. If someone taps your shoulder, you jump. Sensitized, your responses to stimuli are magnified. After de-sensitization, someone taps your shoulder, you turn around and say hi (less intense).

Thanks for the vids. I wouldn't normally correct people on this, but since this is a science video, you might be interested. When you said we are "de-sensitized" to the smell of our own nose - this is actually not true. The correct term is habituated, not de-sensitized. Sensitization occurs in the state system, habituation occurs in a single S-R pathway. Sensitization = all senses on high alert, habituation = one repeated (or constant) stimulus is ignored. When we see a rainbow, we see a continuous spread of the colors from red to violet, but it's the in-betweens that is perhaps most telling. Let's say that we're both looking at solid patches of red and orange. Let's say that what I call red and orange, you perceive as what, to me, would be blue and green. What do we then call the shade that exists between red and orange? I would see an actual color, the mix of my red and orange, while you would see just white.

Your definition of "olfactory" is completely misleading, as the original term has nothing to do with a "factory" (as in a place where things are made)
Olfactory; (def) ADJECTIVE 
1. relating to smelling: used in smelling or relating to the sense of smell
[ Mid-17th century. Via assumed Latin olfactorius "used for smelling" < olfacere "to smell" < olere + facere "do" ] 
Thus, Olfactory has nothing to do with an odor factory but an ability to smell.  It is an anglicization of a Latin word.

A theory is simply the most elaborate form of consistent scientific knowledge not yet disproved by experiment. In experimental sciences, a theory can never be "proved", it can only be "disproved" by experiment. This is precisely what makes a theory scientific. Gravity, cells, atoms, and germs are theories as well. But we take them as "facts" because they work and exist 99.9999999999% of the time. This also applies to evolution and natural selection as biology is an experimental science.

@LeNuiz Actually, different atoms weight different amounts, usually measured in atomic mass units, which are based on a scale around carbon-12--one atom of Carbon-12 is one atomic mass unit. The mass of a group of like atoms, meanwhile, can be bound by dividing the number of atoms by Avogadro's number(~6.022e23), then multiplying that by the element's molar mass, or the mass of one mole of that element(1mol=the same number of atoms in 12 grams of Carbon-12).

The high/low flow nostril concept also explains why when you have a cold, one nostril is always more congested than the other and they switch.  The low flow nostril is unable to dislodge the mucous, and when they switch, one nostril clears up and the other one becomes congested.

It's the same as the neural adaptation for smelling things.  You can't taste your own saliva because it is in constant contact with your tongue, and your brain tunes it out.  If you held some soda or a piece of food in your mouth for a few minutes you would notice that you can no longer taste it.  Someone else's saliva would have a different chemical composition than yours, and so you could taste it.

Others clues include kinetic depth, color saturation, occlusion, shading, texture, and curvilinear perspective.

I love the end of this video because it clarifies the familiar question "If a tree falls in the woods, and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?". The answer is no. Sound happens in the brain (not the ear). Hence, if there isn't a brain to interpret the vibrations of the eardrum (which vibrates because of the pressure shock wave generated by the falling tree), then the sound never occurs.

Real reason with have two nostrils/eyes/arms/legs/etc
Because we evolved from a line of animals that organised their bodies along Bilateral Symmetry. It's like making a Rorschach image, you only have to have a "recipe" for half the thing, then mirror it. We (our line of genetic ancestors going back before humans) had two nostrils first, then we adapted functions for having two nostrils.
it's not like we once had one nostril or one eye and said "hmm, now it would be better if we evolved a 2nd".

Actually water isn't tasteless at all, it's another instance of neural adaptation. Have you ever been to a different town and noticed the water tastes funny? After drinking the water from home so often, your mind is desensitized to that particular taste. Like Michael said, it's to prepare your mind to notice any change in your water supply in order keep you from poisoning yourself.
As for how it feels good to drink water although it's tasteless, I assume that's your self preservation speaking.

It is also the reason for existence of the Yogic Practice of Alternate Nostril breathing, to energize, or to relax, left side, or right.

Space doesn't suck all the atmosphere right off of Earth because of Earth's gravity. Space does not inherently "suck" anything. If we isolate a straw that goes from sea-level up to space, the weight of the atmosphere still wins. I know I exist, but I don't know that YOU do. It's a relativity of perspective. Descartes said "I think, therefore I am." Which means if you wonder about your existence then you must exist. But wondering about someone's ELSE'S existence doesn't prove YOU exist, but it does show that you think! That's the chasm between existentialism and experience. The experience leads to beliefs, which may or may not logically follow from the experience, including whether or not the experience, itself, exists.
